measured_by: single guilt item from the Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS)
justification: Study 1 notes that participants "reported feelings of 'guilt' … using 1 item … as part of the 20-item Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS; Watson et al., 1988)."

measured_by: single shame item from the Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS)
justification: The same passage states that a single PANAS item was also used for “shame,” indicating the scale measured momentary shame.

measured_by: Shortened State Shame and Guilt Scale (SSGS-S) – guilt subscale
justification: Study 3 reports: "The shortened State Shame and Guilt Scale (SSGS-S; Tangney & Dearing, 2002)… assessed state feelings of guilt (e.g., 'I feel remorse, regret')."

measured_by: Shortened State Shame and Guilt Scale (SSGS-S) – shame subscale
justification: The same sentence adds that the SSGS-S "assessed… shame (e.g., 'I feel humiliated, disgraced')."
For anger, the authors write: "To measure anger, we used the 6-item Hostility subscale from the PANAS-X… ('angry', 'irritable')."
Study 2 states that after the scenario, participants "completed the General Just World Belief scale (GBJW: α = .79)."

measured_by: 6-item deservingness scale adapted from Feather et al. (2011)
justification: Under "State Beliefs About Deservingness" the paper says: "we asked 6 questions adapted from Feather et al. (2011)… e.g., 'I deserve to be punished for my actions.'"
Participant screening required them to "pass an online anxiety screener (… Beck et al., 1988)," referring to the Beck Anxiety Inventory.
